H0.text: A decrease in air temperature is most likely to result from small meteoroids entering Earth's atmosphere.

H1.text: The appearance of shooting stars most likely results from small meteoroids entering Earth's atmosphere.

H2.text: An decrease in atmospheric ozone will most likely result from small meteoroids entering the atmosphere of Earth.

H3.text: The appearance of the Northern Lights is the most likely result of small meteoroids entering the atmosphere of Earth.

A4.text: A meteor, known colloquially as a shooting star, is a glowing streak of a small body (usually meteoroid) going through Earth's atmosphere, after being heated to incandescence by collisions with air molecules in the upper atmosphere, creating a streak of light via its rapid motion and sometimes also by shedding glowing material in its wake.
